description: Unique identifier for the system statistics record; typically an auto-incremented primary key.
Categorizes the logged system event to support monitoring, analytics, and alerting.
Application page or API endpoint associated with the event.
Runtime profile or configuration context tied to the event; confirm with SME.
Serialized JSON context captured with the event (runtime parameters, screens, user/session data) used for diagnostics and replay.
Timestamp when the event was recorded; timezone depends on server configuration.
Identifier of a related attachment or artifact linked to the event; likely a file or attachments-table record; confirm with SME.
Timestamp when the reported issue/event was resolved or verified; confirm with SME.
Secondary attachment identifier associated with the event (e.g., linkage between attachments); confirm with SME.
Workflow status of the event or related ticket; confirm with SME.
Priority or severity assigned to the event or ticket for triage; confirm with SME.
Indicates duplication or references the original record when duplicates exist; confirm with SME.
Reference number for the corresponding issue in the external tracker (likely Redmine); confirm with SME.
Free-text internal notes about the event, investigation, or remediation.
Application variant/context where the event occurred.
User-provided comments or metadata associated with the event; may store client IP in practice; confirm with SME.
Username of the signed-in user associated with the event.
Serialized list of recent UI interactions preceding the event, used for issue reproduction and UX analytics.
Raw error payload captured at failure time for troubleshooting and correlation.
Application build/version that generated the event.
User or process that last updated this record.
Timestamp when this record was last updated.
Normalized error code extracted from the error payload for filtering and aggregation.
